John McCabe.Action: Surveys the town with a hidden, resigned expression, showing no open hostility or disdain.
Dresses carefully and with affectation, displaying a desire to present himself well in an inhospitable environment.

Dresses in an incongruous, elaborate outfit (frock coat, ruffled shirt, embroidered vest, gold watch chain) in rough mining country; puts on soldier and cuffs that are too formal for the setting; creates a facade.
Carries an impressive, large-barreled Navy Colt revolver holstered at his side.
His expression hides or reflects internal thoughts ambiguously; sighs in resignation before dismounting.
Surveys the town thoughtfully before proceeding, indicating a cautious awareness.
Tips his hat as a greeting, despite being ignored.
Shows a jaunty, imperturbable facade while miserable and cold.
Ignores saloon proprietor Sheehan's attempts to engage him.
Leads a curious and ragged group of miners along the trail, attracting their attention and interest without hostility or scorn.
Smiles slightly as he brings the group back to Sheehan's saloon, indicating a friendly or at least cordial demeanor.
Leads a group of miners back to Sheehan's saloon, seizing an opportunity for business, showing confidence and awareness of social dynamics.
Smiles slightly while tying his horse, demonstrating composure and self-assurance in a rough environment.
Answers with a warm and friendly smile toward Sheehan.
Moves with confidence through a room full of miners, responding with a warm smile and handling the attention deliberately by playing to the crowd when realizing he is center stage.
Uses ceremony to remove a blanket from his pack horse, demonstrating control and a sense of showmanship rather than hesitation or uncertainty.
Smiles at the miners, ceremoniously spreads the blanket on the table, and involves the group in preparing the game setup.
Uses a cool, matter-of-fact tone to claim a chair, causing Sheehan to act servilely.
Graces each miner with a smile despite their rough appearance and demeanor.
Asserts himself confidently to take a seat despite no open place, commands Sheehan to bring a chair, and handles the table setup with calm authority, gaining cooperation from the miners.
Carefully opens an unopened deck of cards and expertly spreads them on the blanket, showing preparation and skill in managing the situation.
Proposes to split the cost of the whiskey fairly with Sheehan and offers to pay for a bottle on behalf of the miners.
Smiles around at the miners and handles the saloon owner Sheehan with good nature and good humor, impressing those around him.
Carefully pulls out only two dollars to pay for the bottle, showing consideration of his own limited resources.
Acknowledges that he and the miners don’t know each other and tries to create a friendly game environment, demonstrating openness.
Makes the poker game accessible by suggesting a low stake (nickel game) so others can join without losing much.
Eases tension with a lighthearted call 'Jack off,' making the group laugh.
Keeps quiet and does not boast when asked about his violent past and reputation.
Suggests changing the game to a five card stud with a three bet roof, gaining agreement from others.
Deals cards quickly and confidently while attracting intense attention from other players.
Wins very few hands despite playing cautiously in a high-stakes environment.
Maintains a calm and confident demeanor when confronted about his reputation as a gunfighter and previous violent acts.
Denies killing a man when directly accused, maintains a calm demeanor without escalating conflict.
Keeps mostly to himself, says little to nobody, does not engage socially with others.
Studies various hands carefully before making a bet with the care of a no-limit game.
Keeps calm and non-reactive during probing questions about his past and reputation.
Refuses to engage or explain himself in a confrontational or overly social manner.
Loses poker hands consistently but continues to play, drawing others in.
Recognizes competitive threat from another dealer and clearly states he doesn't like competition.
Attempts to negotiate the price for playing poker, showing awareness of value and willingness to bargain.
Admits he is losing badly in the game and tries to adjust the stakes by proposing a quarter instead of a dollar to mitigate loss.
Seeks information about the local population (Chinamen) and potential associated problems (opium use), demonstrating situational awareness.
Despite losing, seems hesitant to move on or quit the game, indicating possible reluctance to cut losses quickly.
Looks sympathetically at men sleeping uncomfortably on the floor, reacts with mild disgust at the poor conditions but does not mock them.
Decides to build his own place of business rather than rely on the existing poor accommodations.
Tosses off a drink after returning from looking at the men sleeping.
Identifies a business opportunity to build his own place of business, showing initiative and vision beyond just gambling.
Observes the poor conditions of the room with sleeping men and decides not to stay, showing practical judgment.
Engages confidently with others and counters doubts about his plan.
Dismisses existing options and sets a challenging goal (building a saloon), which may carry risk but shows confidence.
Confidently plans to open a saloon and brothel despite doubts from others, showing ambition and self-belief.
Positions himself favorably among miners who cheer his plans, indicating he can inspire support and friendliness.
Plans to open a whorehouse despite the town being small and doubted by others, showing calculated optimism and business foresight.
Expresses confidence in his gambling skills and makes a small bet on himself, indicating self-assurance and skill.
Negotiates firmly over opium price, acknowledges previous payments, and insists on fair terms despite pressure.
Accepts some empathy and advice from Old Man to calm down, showing tolerance to others.
Regards the Indian girl with concern, hoping she makes it through the winter.
Negotiates prices for prostitutes but complains about the cost and difficulty of making a living.
Considers buying three prostitutes despite their poor condition and high price; negotiates prices with Archer.
Questions the need to spend so much money on prostitutes, showing awareness of costliness.
Expresses reluctance to work for Bearpaw Territorial Mining, showing preference for independence.
Peers out window, attracted by the men singing a religious song, showing attention to others' activities.

Owns and operates a partially completed building intended to be a saloon and gambling hall, living and working on the second floor; monitors activity on the street while shaving, indicating awareness of surroundings.

Only the second floor of his establishment is completed and in use, with the rest still under construction, suggesting gradual progress but not full readiness or full implementation of his business plan.
Looks around the town possessively from his vantage point, calculating how much money the line is worth to him.
Calculates how much money the line is worth to him from his vantage point, assessing his potential profit.
Looks around the town possessively, showing awareness and a sense of control over his domain.
Responds coldly to Sheehan's attempt at friendliness and downplays common ground between them.
Directly calls out Sheehan's flattery as insincere and demands honesty.
Asserts his preferred form of address calmly and with confidence when Sheehan calls him 'Pudgey'.
Rejects superficial camaraderie and points out limited common ground with Sheehan, showing skepticism and awareness.
Accurately calls out Sheehan's flattery as 'a lotta crap' and exposes the real reason behind it, demonstrating insight and no-nonsense attitude.
Disengages quickly from Sheehan and avoids getting drawn into unnecessary conflict despite insults, maintaining composure.
Shows emotional detachment and coldness in social interactions (e.g., reacting coldly to informal address), which may indicate social rigidity or limited warmth.
Proposes a partnership with Sheehan to maintain control over saloon openings, showing a willingness to collaborate.
Continues shaving calmly while waiting for Sheehan's reaction, showing a measured and patient demeanor.
Proposes a strategic partnership with Sheehan to control saloon competition and maintain influence in the town.
Continues calmly shaving while discussing important business matters, demonstrating composure and confidence.
Reacting quickly to a sudden disturbance by rushing to the window to assess a fight outside, showing alertness and responsiveness.
Stands quietly near the fight, then intervenes to stop the violence by challenging the main aggressor, showing control and a desire to prevent further harm.
Tells Tiny to get a gun if he wants to fight, enforcing his dominance but without resorting to violence himself, indicating a tough but fair attitude.
Commands the bullies to put the tent back up and line up, and promises to forget the incident if they comply, showing fairness and tolerance.
Smiles when the church bell rings and states he never wants to kill anyone on Sunday, revealing a humane and somewhat moral side.
Throws three dollars toward Sheehan and abruptly ends discussion about their partnership without further explanation.
Greeted Bob Webster warmly and inquired about troubles, showing interest in others.
Tips his hat politely to Mrs. Webster and Mrs. Miller, welcomes them warmly to the church and town.
Offers Ida and Bob Webster a temporary place to stay and promises to help them get a sawmill set up soon.
Shows concern and sympathy toward Ida Webster, who looks frightened and vulnerable.
Offers a polite greeting and gestures to talk alone with Constance in the saloon.
Sets up a bottle and two glasses for Constance, despite her declining a drink.
Responds to Constance's teasing about cologne with a non-defensive apology ('I don't feel nothing but sorry it bothers you, Madame').
Dismissing Constance's wit remark with a wave rather than engaging.
Responds politely to Constance, maintains composure in social interaction, sets up the bar in preparation to talk.
Shows awareness of social dynamics by addressing Constance with a formal title and handling the situation calmly.
Dismisses a sarcastic remark with a wave of his hand, indicating confidence and control of the interaction.
Does not insist or become confrontational when Constance rejects his light; remains silent instead of pushing the conversation.
Offers Constance a job despite her calling herself a whore, shows pragmatic tolerance.
Laughs off Constance's proposal somewhat skeptically but listens to her ideas.
Questions ability to handle problems like drunks or emotional girls, showing some doubt but openness to discussion.
Refers to prostitutes dismissively as 'crib cows,' showing lack of respect toward women in that line of work.
Considers Constance's proposal seriously but expresses doubts and reveals he is a gambler who doesn't take chances.
Has not asked himself important operational questions about handling workers and troubles in running a whorehouse, indicating potential naivety or lack of experience.
Confidently states he has been doing all right so far and already planned to build a house, showing self-assurance and some prior planning.
Offers Constance a drink and touches her wedding band, showing attention to her feelings.
Attempts to build Constance a house and listens to her conditions (bath house first).
Reluctantly orders the unloading lumber to be reloaded when Constance demands a bath house first, despite financial strain.
Complains about the lack of immediate income but respects Constance's rule about not taking customers until bath house is built.
Offers to build a house and tries to manage construction logistics effectively (orders reloading lumber when conditions are not right).
Shows hesitation and anger when confronted with additional demands (bath house before using lumber), struggling to see how to finance it without income.
Engages in business negotiation with Mrs. Miller, showing awareness of local conditions and practical challenges.
Orders the lumber to be reloaded and tries to establish a bath house business despite skeptical locals.
Expresses concern about financing the bath house due to lack of gambling income, showing awareness of financial challenges.
Moves to Mrs. Miller's tent late at night while drunk and scratches on the flap to get her attention.
Moves confidently between tents, attempts to enter Mrs. Miller's tent despite being drunk.
Admits to being broke and honest about his financial situation despite town perceptions.
Expresses frustration with Mrs. Miller over money spent and demand for prostitutes.
Refuses to come into Mrs. Miller's tent despite being drunk, showing restraint.
Admits to being broke despite town thinking he is rich, confronts Mrs. Miller about financial losses and delays in getting whores, takes initiative to inquire about business operations.
Appears drunk while addressing business concerns, showing impaired judgment and lack of control.
Confronts Constance bluntly about expenses and frustrations, expressing his financial troubles honestly.
Refuses to join others waiting in line for the girls, asserting his independence strongly.
Expresses frustration about financial losses and delays but maintains awareness of his situation and insists on knowing when the workers (whores) will arrive.
Refuses to appear drunk or vulnerable despite criticism, showing composure.
Recklessly spends money on whore transportation and a brothel despite being broke, indicating poor financial management.
Organizes for the arrival of the girls and prepares the whorehouse despite bad weather and difficult conditions.
Does not appear directly in the excerpt but indirectly shown as not effectively communicating or assisting with locating Mrs. Miller's whorehouse leading to confusion among the girls.
Comes to the tent not as a customer but to wish Mrs. Miller well.
Shows anger when confronted with the price for service and cannot conceal it.
Approaches the tent confidently and interacts with Mrs. Miller and Constance with a degree of politeness and strategic ambiguity.
Attempts to inquire about the services in a way that conceals his true intent, showing social tact and control.
Shows anger that he cannot conceal when confronted with the pricing, indicating some loss of composure.
Says 'I wish you well, Madame' to Constance as he walks away without looking back.
Keeps himself from turning back despite wanting to hear Constance's answer to the men's offers.
Is angry with himself for caring whether Constance 'screws every man in town or not'.
Expresses frustration that Mrs. Miller has cost him money and insists that the losses must stop.
Impatiently corrects his own mistake when counting money and gives an impatient glance at Mrs. Miller.
Defensively tells Mrs. Miller to keep out of things she does not understand despite her claim of partnership.
Closes and locks the saloon door, attempts to count the money from the strongbox, shows impatience but proceeds with counting despite making mistakes.
Claims his books show he needs money, but his accounting appears confused or inaccurate as Mrs. Miller finds the books impossible to understand.
Expresses frustration and tries to assert authority when questioned about his bookkeeping, revealing possible insecurity about his financial management skills.
Acknowledges that despite a busy business day, he has not seen any money, indicating awareness of cash flow issues.
Dismisses Constance's involvement with the books and business affairs, asserts control and dominance.
Responds sarcastically and condescendingly to Constance's planning and suggestions.
Uses a dismissive gender stereotype to exclude Constance from managing financial records.
Despite dismissing Constance, does not resort to overt hostility or aggression.
Dismisses Constance's request to see the books and insists certain businesses are solely his, showing defensiveness and lack of transparency.
Acknowledges the importance of the opium trade candidly, indicating some awareness of his business's underpinnings.
Mocks Constance’s ambitions and insults her intelligence, revealing poor interpersonal skills and insecurity.
Fails to answer simple arithmetic questions related to his business finances promptly, showing inadequate numerical literacy.
Expresses confidence in his own intelligence sarcastically but is contradicted by his inability to handle basic bookkeeping.
Confidently manages financial details and game odds, showing competence.
Shouts after Constance correcting her math in a frustrated tone.
Asserts control over timing of building the whorehouse, dismissing others' input.
Stands calmly nearby Constance Miller and the girls during the wrestling match, maintaining composure amidst the chaotic scene.
Does not intervene or react noticeably to the violent outcome of the wrestling match involving his miner.
Organizes and initiates a town tug-of-war contest, offers whiskey to participants as a friendly gesture.
Drinks heavily and sways drunkenly during the event but is enjoying himself and engaging with others.
Ignores the card handed by Sears without properly acknowledging it or engaging seriously.
Fires a Colt pistol to start a tug-of-war contest involving most men in town, displaying confidence and a commanding presence despite being drunk.
Carries a bottle of whiskey while managing and organizing a large event, showing an ability to lead and maintain control even under the influence.
Hands a card to Eugene Sears but does not properly read or focus on it, indicating inattentiveness and possible lack of awareness.
Responds to Eugene Sears with a vague and confused introduction, struggling to focus on the situation, reflecting a lack of sharpness at this moment.
Rejects Sears' handshake coldly and moves away, signalling distrust and unwillingness to engage.
Responds sarcastically and curtly to Sears' attempts at conversation, showing bluntness and skepticism.
Refuses a buyout offer with sharp dismissal, showing confidence and clear understanding of his position.
Successfully fires a gunshot accurately despite appearing drunk, demonstrating skill and expertise.
Ignores the easily reachable bottle of whiskey while soaking in the bath, showing self-control and focus instead of indulgence.
Absent from Mrs. Miller's lively party, suggesting possible social withdrawal or avoidance compared to other men present.
Approaches Mrs. Miller's bedroom door nonchalantly, leaning casually with folded arms.
Claims ownership of the town to celebrate, displays playful and familiar interaction with Constance, accepts her care and bath invitation.
Picks up and kisses Constance hard on the mouth as he enters, showing physical affection.
Lies next to Mrs. Miller under the covers, sharing intimacy that suggests a sincere connection despite her past experiences.
Reaches out sleepily to embrace Mrs. Miller in the morning, indicating tenderness and affection.
Confidently asserts himself by claiming ownership of the town and celebrates loudly despite Constance's hostility.
Engages in a physical and affectionate gesture towards Constance, showing assertiveness and control in social interaction.
Appears relaxed and at ease in intimate situations, maintaining composure and calmness after a night spent with Mrs. Miller.
Is slow to awaken and initially passive in bed, suggesting possible lethargy or lack of alertness.
Invites Constance back to bed, showing desire for closeness.
Insults Constance by calling her 'cheap son-of-a-bitch' and angry shouting designed to hurt.
Expresses frustration and anger but ultimately engages in a serious negotiation to sell business, indicating willingness to provide for Constance.
Refuses to sell out to the mining company to protect his self-respect and reputation despite pressure.
Insists on paying money to Constance despite hostility, showing sincerity and honor.
Engages in a sharp exchange with Constance, hitting below the belt.
Looks out from his bedroom window at Mrs. Miller's house before leaving town, indicating a moment of contemplation or concern.
Calls Elliott 'God's dead, you prick,' showing hostility and disrespect.
Rides out of town alert and acutely aware of the possibility of being shot, indicating wariness and self-preservation but no clear warmth.
Finishes packing carefully, straps on his gun, spins the cylinder while preparing to leave, showing readiness and awareness.
Looks out the bedroom window to observe the rear of Mrs. Miller's house, indicating vigilance and situational awareness.
Rides out of town but turns back to look at the town, showing a reflective or cautious attitude.
Verbally insults Elliott ('God's dead, you prick') before leaving, showing potential emotional impulsiveness or lack of diplomatic skill.
Rides into town at night very alert and acutely aware of the possibility of being shot, demonstrating prudence and cautiousness.
Rides into town alert and prepared for danger, carrying a shotgun ready.
Carefully surveys the street before entering the lawyer's office.
Confidently admits to some skill with a shotgun during conversation, demonstrating self-awareness and readiness.
Openly acknowledges the impracticality of stopping the mining company alone when told by the lawyer, showing realistic appraisal.
Admits uncertainty about why he wants to fight the mining company, showing possible lack of clarity in motivation.
Refuses to sell out to the Company despite pressure, stands his ground.
Signs legal papers without fully comprehending all details but trusts the Lawyer.
Dives off his horse and immediately draws his pistol upon hearing a gunshot in a saloon.
Expresses fear and awareness of danger, showing vulnerability.
Asks Mrs. Miller if she is smiling because she is glad he's back, showing desire for emotional connection.
Makes a sarcastic, cold comment about whores not being little girls, indicating insensitivity.
Stares at Mrs. Miller and tries to figure out how many times she sold herself while he was gone, showing suspicion and possible mistrust.
Confesses to hiring a lawyer, implying he takes responsibility for his problems.
Shows awareness of the business nature of Constance's work and discusses it openly with her, indicating practical understanding of interpersonal and situational dynamics.
Admits he did not talk to the Mining Company when asked, which suggests a lack of proactive communication or follow-through regarding a presumably important matter.
States that he hired a good lawyer despite not speaking to the Mining Company, showing some initiative and planning in legal matters.
Confidently faces threats and intimidation without escalating conflict, remaining deadly quiet and composed.
Invites Constance back to bed in a familiar and casual manner, indicating a personal connection.
Ignores provocative insults and threats from Patrick Sheehan instead of responding aggressively.
Hires a good lawyer, indicating planning and proactiveness.
Refuses to show fear or reaction when threatened by Sheehan, maintaining control and confidence.
Silently and calmly responds with 'Good night' to Sheehan's provocation, suggesting composure and strategic restraint.
Confronts Sheehan firmly but leaves with a cold 'Good night.'
Watches Tiny Newcombe leave wishing him good luck.
Expresses frustration about the town being turned against him due to zinc rates.
Suggests the clerk write to the governor to report cheating by the company.
Angrily confronts the clerk about illegal practices harming the people.
Feels frightened and cautious when facing an unfamiliar, threatening situation on an empty street; prepares himself by arming and checking weapons before looking out for danger.
Realizes the street is deserted and unsafe, notices he has no gun, quickly retreats back inside for protection.
Moves cautiously and quickly to secure his firearm and checks the situation from a position of safety.
Becomes visibly tense and frightened facing an unknown threat in a deserted street.
Interacts calmly with miners reporting a threat, listens attentively to their information.
Initially confrontational with miners rushing in, pointing a shotgun at them.
Does not immediately panic or show fear about the threat, maintains composure.
Moves carefully down the stairs and holds a shotgun ready when miners rush in unexpectedly.
Calmly questions miners for information about the gunslinger sent to kill him, seeking details before taking action.
Does not immediately panic or act rashly upon hearing about the threat, instead assesses the situation with collected questions.
Leaves town riders uncertain about the gunfighter's presence by mounting his horse and riding out confidently.
Moves out without getting an accurate picture of the gunman, showing a possible oversight in information gathering.
Welcomes Mrs. Miller politely into his office with a courteous invitation to come in.
Expresses concern about being assassinated but engages in candid conversation with Mrs. Miller, showing some openness.
Insists on personally doing the books to avoid loose ends, showing a responsible and sincere attitude.
Spins his revolver's cylinder making an annoying clicking noise, which provokes discomfort in Constance.
Refuses to get help and insists on handling the fight himself because of reputation, indicating pride and mistrust of others.
Admits to helping the Chinese only when it was beneficial, and denies owing them anything.
Responds factually that Danny is just a bartender when asked about him, neither warm nor cold.
Expresses awareness of danger and the need to protect himself, showing self-preservation and vigilance.
Insists on doing the bookkeeping himself to avoid loose ends, demonstrating responsibility and thoroughness.
Spins the cylinder of his revolver habitually, indicating nervousness or distraction.
Dismisses idea of getting help because he feels he must handle fights alone, revealing confidence but possible unwillingness to delegate or collaborate.
Helps others (the Chinamen) only when it benefits him, showing pragmatic and self-interested decision-making.
Scans the town carefully looking for a place of advantage and possible threat, prepares for ambush with caution and calculation.
Smiles and spares the young cowboy from being shot despite initial suspicion.
Engages in playful, slightly teasing conversation with Constance but shows concern about the town and situation.
Responds irritably to Constance's critiques, telling her she causes him pain, then retreats to his room slamming the door.
Commands the young cowboy to pick up his gun and behave himself, maintaining control of the situation.
Smiles calmly after defusing a potentially violent encounter, showing confidence and composure.
Stands by the window staring out, worrying about an impending threat instead of taking action.
Engages in tense, confrontational banter with Mrs. Miller but does not lose control.
Stomps and slams his bedroom door shut in frustration.
Wakes suddenly in bed in apparent fear without any visible reason or preparation.
Secures the door, prepares to defend the saloon with caution and care.
Displays intense fear and readiness for violence, focused on self-protection rather than trust or friendliness.
Sits bolt upright in bed suddenly, aware of danger.
Carefully looks out the window without making himself a target, listening intently.
Inspects the horses outside and notes the large rifle prominently displayed.
Secures the bolt on the outside door before dressing.
Moves through saloon cautiously with shotgun ready, scanning entrances and exits.
Analyzes spatial relationships and chooses the best defensive spot.
Rearranges furniture to clear firing lines and maximize defense.
Positions himself so he can see the doorway via mirror and by slight turns of his head.
Locks front door and settles down calmly with shotgun and cigar, prepared for attack.
Reassures Danny not to worry about the threat, tries to ease his bartender's nerves.
Offers Danny the task of serving the potential attackers, showing trust in his ability despite Danny's uncertainty.
Exhibits a cold, tense demeanor by not moving all day and silently awaiting a threat, showing little outward emotional warmth.
Calmly prepares for potential conflict, maintains control and reassures Danny despite threat.
Allows Danny to serve potential hostile visitors, trusting his bartender to handle situation.
Shows reluctance and uncertainty by pausing and not immediately entering his own saloon.
Tells Danny to move behind the bar and not place himself in danger.
Sits silently holding a shotgun pointed at the door to protect against intruders.
Offers to buy the first drink of the day for Butler and others, shares cigars.
Concedes about killing Bill Roundtree honestly without evasion.
Keeps shotgun trained on Butler when he approaches, showing guardedness and distrust.
Engages in rough but amicable banter and allows Butler his space.
Confidently recounts killing Bill Roundtree accurately and without hesitation.
Handles potentially dangerous interaction with Butler calmly, maintaining control with shotgun ready.
Offers first drink and maintains social dominance in the bar setting, showing social intelligence.
Uses humor and straightforwardness in conversation, effectively managing tension.
Does not back down or show fear when sizing up an old killer, shows confidence but could be risky.
Gives cigars to Mr. Butler's friends, showing a gesture of goodwill.
Keeps calm and responds with a smile when Butler taunts him, displaying restraint and tolerance.
Warns the Kid to control his voice when talking tough, showing a protective or mentoring attitude.
Says he never wanted to kill anybody again, implying remorse and possibly a desire for peacefulness.
Carries a shotgun pointed steadily at Butler, maintaining control and intimidating him without immediate violence.
Remains silent and smiling when Butler tests and provokes him verbally, showing calm confidence.
Warns the Kid not to let his voice crack when talking tough, indicating awareness and command in tense social interactions.
Simply states he never wanted to kill again, defusing Butler's provocation with a straightforward, composed response.
Defuses a potentially violent showdown by warning the Kid not to spit again and preventing confrontation with Butler.
Moves quickly to gain tactical advantage over Butler suggesting readiness for violence.
Moves his shotgun confidently to control a tense confrontation, effectively preventing escalation.
Responds calmly to gunfire, assesses the distance of shots accurately, and quickly puts up a 'No Guns' sign to control the situation inside the saloon.
Chooses to sit on the opposite side of the room to maintain a tactical advantage and manage the threat strategically.
Displays casual personal appearance (unshaven, undressed with usual care) potentially signaling neglect or fatigue but still maintains control of the situation.
Ignores the concerns of Danny about the sign possibly provoking trouble, confident in his approach to handling the situation.
Offers understanding and kindness to Danny amid slow business and Danny wanting to quit, showing leadership and interpersonal competence.
Moves to get Danny's money, thinking he would do the same if roles were reversed.
Agrees to pay Danny his three days' wages without argument, showing fairness and consideration.
Pushes the bureau against the door as a barricade, indicating a defensive and prepared stance.
Seems frustrated and curses ('Goddamn whores'), showing some emotional agitation.
Lies awake listening to gunfire, showing signs of stress and alertness but does not engage or confront others.
Sneaks out of bedroom cautiously, alert to slightest sound, indicating wariness and self-protection rather than sociability.
Moves a bureau to open a hidden space, then loosens a wooden step, actions indicating secrecy and distrust rather than openness.
Carefully sets traps (rigged steps, barricaded office) and remains alert to potential threats, demonstrating caution and concern for his safety.
Looks at himself in the mirror with a moment of self-awareness and stops drinking, showing some sincerity and introspection.
Smiles and shakes his head after being startled by a rigged step, indicating a moment of calm humor or self-restraint.
Is depicted as unshaven, disheveled, and worn down, drinking alone, which suggests internal struggle but does not directly inform warmth trait.
Rigged steps to detect intruders and barricaded door to office, showing cautious preparation and strategic defense.
Maintains vigilant positions with shotgun ready, scanning surroundings closely and listening intently.
Recognizes his own boots causing noise, preventing a needless gunshot.
Fights sleep while on guard, showing dedication despite physical fatigue.
Pauses mid-drink upon seeing his rough appearance in the mirror, indicating self-awareness but also signs of neglect and exhaustion.
Moves carefully on rigged noisy steps, raising his shotgun reflexively and then relaxing when realizing it was a false alarm.
At one point looks pumpled and dirty, no derby, unshaven, and exhausted-looking; possible sign of deteriorating condition.
Smiles and shakes his head after mistaking a noisy step for an intruder, then moves into his bedroom calmly.
There is no direct action in this excerpt indicating warmth or coldness from McCabe himself; the violent scene involves other characters (Kid, Breed), not McCabe.
Dresses carefully, presents himself with confidence but without weapons, walks into danger knowingly.
Lights a cigar calmly at the sight of a dead man, showing no visible emotional reaction.
Dresses carefully and presents himself with clear eyes and confidence before facing danger unarmed.
Approaches 'Sheehan’s' saloon cautiously, scanning for ambush and aware of the danger.
Lights a cigar calmly upon seeing the dead body, showing composed demeanor in tense situation.
Moves toward Sheehan’s despite knowing he is in danger and unarmed.
Walks into a dangerous situation unarmed, showing courage and trustworthiness.
Tips his hat carefully to show he is unarmed and means no harm.
Asks the ladies to stay and buys drinks for everyone, proposing a toast to diffuse tension.
Uses firm and dismissive language toward Kid ('This conversation's for grown ups, sonny').
Dresses carefully and confidently for a dangerous confrontation, unarmed but calm.
Approaches enemy saloon aware of danger, scouts for ambush, observes carefully before entering.
Lights cigar calmly after noticing dead cowboy, indicating composed and unshaken demeanor.
Enters saloon carefully, unarmed, demonstrating confidence and control of situation.
Uses verbal dominance to control conversation, asserting he's unarmed and commanding respect.
Takes a risk entering hostile environment unarmed; while risky, he demonstrates confident calculation.
Does not escalate violence but instead proposes a toast, showing social skill and strategic thinking.
Proposes a toast including everyone, engages in convivial drinking.
Openly admits his low chance of survival and accepts fate honestly.
Invites others to bet on his survival, showing trust and openness.
Uses blunt and tough language, but in a straightforward and sincere manner.
Openly admits the high risk of his situation but remains confident, calculating the odds intelligently and facing the danger head-on.
Encourages others to participate in his challenge, showing leadership and understanding of the stakes involved.
Shows no overconfidence despite the danger, realistically assessing the odds against him.
Organizes and participates in a betting arrangement, covers a partner's bet with some of his own money, and handles the money responsibly and fairly.
Counts and stacks money expertly, smiles politely to others.
Puts the wager money securely in his pocket, despite a veiled threat, then ignores the insult about his woman.
Moves warily between locations armed and dresses well, showing care and respect to Mrs. Miller by removing his slicker when entering.
Responds calmly to implied threats and does not engage in provocations.
Counts and stacks the money expertly, showing careful handling of cash and confidence.
Puts the entire wager into his pocket and moves confidently towards the door, implying trust in his own security measures.
Ignores Butler's confidential and possibly threatening implication about his woman, showing calmness and emotional control.
Moves warily but confidently armed with pistol and shotgun while navigating the environment, showing preparedness and caution.
Enters Mrs. Miller's unlocked door by twisting the knob while knocking, demonstrating an easy familiarity with the place and assertiveness.
Enters Mrs. Miller's home confidently but respectfully, noting her relief to see him.
Engages in casual storytelling about a dangerous encounter with Indians, showing a sense of humor and openness.
Admits to being a gambler and accepts the consequences of his bet with a matter-of-fact tone.
Wears weapons into Mrs. Miller's home despite her discomfort, indicating a lack of consideration.
Moves warily between locations armed with weapons, indicating cautiousness and preparedness.
Engages in a bet despite known dangers, identifying himself as a gambler who takes calculated risks.
Remembers and recounts a clever escape from Indians by using psychological tactics and knowledge of their behavior.
Does not directly address Constance’s concerns or stop making risky decisions despite warnings.
Reassures Constance that no harm will come to her, shows concern for her safety.
Apologizes sincerely for upsetting Constance by handling his pistol, acknowledges her feelings.
Admits he is not good at saying sorry but expresses genuine regret and closeness to Constance.
Begins an argument about worry but stops to avoid confrontation.
Remembers a past encounter with Indians and uses this to demonstrate his awareness and survival skills.
Checks and flips his pistol confidently, showing readiness and skill with his weapon.
Puts the pistol away promptly after Constance expresses discomfort, showing emotional intelligence and respect.
Admits he is not good at saying sorry, revealing some social or emotional awkwardness.
Insists on caring deeply and tries to communicate this despite communication difficulties.
Engages in tension-filled dialogue rather than resolving conflict calmly.
Asks Constance for an invitation warmly and poetically, expressing affection and vulnerability.
Snuggles tightly against Constance, strokes her hair gently, and kisses her tenderly, showing sincere intimacy and caring.
Expresses a desire to pick wildflowers for Constance, a tender and thoughtful gesture.
Admits he has poetry in him and tries to share his feelings sincerely.
Asks for invitation to be close to Constance, tries to create a romantic mood by requesting dim lights and expresses feelings openly.
Struggles to articulate emotions clearly ('If I knew how to do Romeo and Juliet...') but persists in communicating genuinely.
Shows attentiveness and sensitivity when noticing something unusual in Constance's hair, indicating careful observation and concern.
Seems hesitant or awkward in physical intimacy, gradually undressing and seeking permission, not overconfident or pushy.
Expresses deep longing for Constance's warmth and a desire to make her smile.
Feels protective and jealous, hates the thought of others being with Constance while he is away.
Struggles to verbally express his feelings of love sincerely.
Quietly watches over Mrs. Miller while she sleeps, then cautiously checks on his saloon, showing care and responsibility.
Stands thoughtfully at the window assessing his saloon in the rain, moves carefully and cautiously to inspect the situation.
Struggles to express his feelings verbally, unable to say 'I love you' directly to Constance.
Moves cautiously and silently to avoid ambush, checks surroundings carefully, seeks safe passage stealthily.
Carefully scout the area for an ambush, finds no signs of danger.
Avoids main foot bridge and uses the ditch to move stealthily despite rain and mud.
Inspects the stair step carefully, notices the step has been disturbed indicating weight applied recently.
Moves cautiously and silently while checking surroundings from multiple angles, takes cover under bridge and moves on foot carefully.
Uses church door as a refuge, listens carefully for any signs of threat, shows situational awareness.
Looks carefully around the town from the bell tower, showing cautious observation rather than trust or openness.
Leaves his shotgun at the bottom of the ladder to climb, showing some trust in his setting and absence of immediate paranoia.
Carefully scouts the town from the bell tower, taking in a detailed layout and monitoring for any signs of danger.
Attempts to climb the ladder with a cumbersome shotgun but wisely decides to leave it behind before climbing.
Pauses to consider his observations about the church but defers thoughtful analysis until later.
Listens stoically as his saloon is shot to pieces without reacting impulsively or panicking.
Observes Butler’s gestures and notices the direction Butler takes while planning their search.
Moves deliberately in the opposite direction of the enemies while they split up to search for him, showing tactical awareness.
Attempts to reason calmly with Elliott who is threatening him with a shotgun, explaining the danger to both of them and others.
Calls Elliott a 'bible-back son-of-a-bitch' in frustration.
Refuses to abandon the fight despite danger and prays silently for strength, showing perseverance and concern for others' safety.
Considers using his gun against Kid but hesitates due to distance and circumstances, indicating restraint and lack of cruelty.
Shows internal conflict about fighting without a gun, acknowledging the sin of murder, reflecting a moral awareness.
Realizes that taking the gun and leaving will prevent further damage to the church and potentially protect others from violence.
Acknowledges that going up against the men without a gun is essentially suicide and refuses to engage unarmed, showing self-awareness and a realistic appraisal of the situation.
Carefully peeks around the corner and attempts to aim at Kid despite unfavorable conditions, demonstrating cautiousness and tactical thinking.
Does not take a reckless shot at Kid despite desire to kill him, recognizing the distance as a limiting factor, showing restraint and tactical sense.
Shoots the Kid in a tense standoff after carefully trying to anticipate his moves, showing no hesitation to use violence.
Carefully observes Kid's nervous gun cocking to time his movements and attempt to close distance stealthily.
Takes a difficult, risky shot while maintaining composure, leading to wounding Kid.
Mistakes timing by making too much noise on muddy ground, alerting Kid momentarily.
Despite being shot in the leg, he manages to get to his feet, forces a locked door open, and gets inside a building to take cover.
Remains seated and watches Breed carefully through the window, pointing a gun at him while anticipating Breed's approach.
Conceals a tiny derringer and uses it to kill Dog Butler when threatened, showing readiness for violence rather than trust or friendliness.
Pulls himself out of the ditch after being attacked, speaks to Sheehan in a somewhat teasing manner ('You never was much of a gambler'), indicating a dry, possibly sardonic interpersonal style.
